مذہبی زور سے تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ کی تبصرے جیسے ال میزان اور توسی کے ایٹ تبیان نے اکثر امامہ (خدائی طور پر مقرر قیادت) کے عینک کے ذریعہ تھامود کی بغاوت کا آغاز کیا ، اور ان کے بعد کے سیاق و سباق میں جائز اتھارٹی کو مسترد کرنے کے متوازی طور پر ان کے مسترد ہونے کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی فریم ورک کے ساتھ منسلک ہے جو فرقہ وارانہ راستبازی کے لئے رہنمائی قیادت کی ضرورت کو ترجیح دیتا ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، ریزی (مافاتیہ الغیب) اور ابن کتھیر جیسے سنی اسکالرز انفرادی اخلاقی ذمہ داری پر زیادہ توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، جس میں تگھوا کو ذاتی تکبر اور اجتماعی اخلاقی زوال کے طور پر تجزیہ کرتے ہوئے قیادت کی تمثیلوں سے واضح رابطے کے بغیر تجزیہ کیا گیا ہے۔ قربانی کا قانونی پر مبنی طافسر عہد کو توڑنے کے فقہی مضمرات پر زور دیتا ہے ، جو اخلاقی قانونی اصولوں کو اخذ کرنے میں سنی علمی طور پر ترجیحات کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔

یہ تشریحی اختلافات تاریخی سیاق و سباق کی شکل میں الگ الگ مذہبی ترجیحات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: قیادت کے جواز پر شیعہ زور دینے سے جانشینی کے بارے میں ابتدائی معاشرے کی جدوجہد کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ سنی انفرادی تقویٰ پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں جس میں وسیع تر سنی کے فقہی اور عقلی پیشرفتوں کے ساتھ منسلک ہوتا ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات بنیادی قرآنی اصولوں کو تقویت دینے کے لئے اس آیت کو استعمال کرتی ہیں: خدائی رہنمائی پر عمل کرنے کی ضرورت اور غیر چیک شدہ خطا کے وجودی خطرات۔ مشترکہ اخلاقی پیغام فرقہ وارانہ حدود سے بالاتر ہے ، یہاں تک کہ مذہبی فریم ورک اس کی کثیر جہتی تفہیم کو تقویت بخشتے ہیں۔

12.layer1:
In Surah Ash-Shams, verse 12, Allah recounts the story of the people of Thamud, who rejected Prophet Salih’s message and violated a sacred covenant by killing a miraculous she-camel sent as a divine test. The phrase *إِذِ ٱنۢبَعَثَ أَشْقَىٰهَا* ("When the most wretched of them was sent forth") refers to the pivotal moment when the worst individual among them, driven by arrogance and greed, took the initiative to slaughter the camel. This act symbolized their collective moral collapse and defiance of Allah’s command.  

Historically, classical Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* identify this "most wretched" figure as Qudar ibn Salif, whose rebellion epitomized the community’s spiritual decay. The term *أشْقَىٰهَا* (ashqaha) derives from *shaqā* (misery), denoting one consumed by moral bankruptcy and destined for eternal ruin. The verb *ٱنۢبَعَثَ* (inba’atha) implies a sudden, impulsive surge toward evil, highlighting how sin often begins with a single individual’s choice to act on base desires.  

This verse serves as a timeless warning against prioritizing material gain or societal approval over divine principles. In modern contexts, it calls Muslims to reflect on how individual actions—like spreading corruption, injustice, or greed—can trigger collective harm. Just as Thamud’s fate was sealed by their complicity in Qudar’s crime, today’s believers must actively resist societal pressures that normalise oppression or unethical behaviour. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, emphasised that true faith requires courage to confront wrongdoing, even if one stands alone. By nurturing self-awareness and accountability, Muslims can embody the Quranic ideal of *amr bil ma’ruf* (enjoining good) and avoid the spiritual "wretchedness" that leads societies astray.
12.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis of Quran 91:12, commentators emphasize the moral and theological dimensions of the Thamud narrative, focusing on the archetypal struggle between divine guidance and human transgression. The phrase "the most wretched of them was sent forth" (idh inbaʿatha ashqāhā) refers to the emergence of Qudar ibn Salif, the man who spearheaded the killing of the sacred she-camel—a divine miracle granted to Prophet Salih’s community as both a test and a mercy. Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* identifies this figure as the epitome of moral corruption, noting that his leadership in violating the sacred covenant exemplifies how societal deviation begins with the empowerment of those most spiritually bankrupt (*ahl al-baghy*). 

Al-Mizan by Tabatabai expands this analysis metaphysically, framing Qudar’s action as the culmination of a collective rejection of *wilayah* (divine guardianship). The Thamud’s failure to honor the she-camel—a symbol of God’s authority mediated through prophetic signs—parallels, in Shia theology, the rejection of the Imams’ spiritual authority after the Prophet. This verse thus becomes a cautionary tale about communities that privilege worldly power (*taghut*) over divine stewardship. 

Both commentators stress that "the most wretched" (al-ashqā) is not merely an individual but a manifestation of systemic moral decay. As narrated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, such figures emerge when societies abandon *amr bil-maʿruf* (enjoining good), allowing corruption to institutionalize. The verse’s placement within Surah al-Shams—which opens with cosmic oaths—underscores the ontological gravity of opposing divine order. Jurisprudentially, this narrative reinforces the Shia emphasis on the necessity of divinely guided leadership to prevent societal collapse into *ashqā*-like tyranny, a principle foundational to Shia political theology.
12.layer3:
In Surah Ash-Shams, verse 12 highlights the emergence of societal corruption through the archetype of "the most wretched" — a figure who embodies moral bankruptcy and collective destruction. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, contextualize this verse beyond its historical reference to Thamud’s rejection of Prophet Salih, framing it as a timeless warning against systems of oppression and individual moral decay. The "most wretched" (ashqa) is interpreted not merely as a historical villain but as a symbol of any force that prioritizes greed, exploitation, or tyranny over communal welfare and divine ethics.  

Modern scholarship intersects with this idea through frameworks like environmental ethics. The verse’s allusion to the destruction of Salih’s she-camel — a symbol of natural balance — resonates with today’s climate crisis, where corporate greed and unsustainable practices mirror the "wretchedness" of exploiting sacred resources. Philosophers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to the Quranic concept of *khalifa* (stewardship), urging accountability for ecological harm as a form of social injustice.  

Socially, the verse critiques systemic inequities, from authoritarian regimes to economic disparities, where the "most wretched" thrive through division and exploitation. Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Mahdi Institute, draw parallels with Christian teachings on structural sin and Buddhist insights on collective karma, fostering solidarity in addressing global crises.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern societies to confront the "wretchedness" within institutional apathy and individual complicity, urging a revival of prophetic values — justice, compassion, and ecological harmony — as antidotes to contemporary moral and existential threats.
12.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), the verse "When the most wretched of them was sent forth" (91:12) unveils profound truths about spiritual corruption and the consequences of opposing divine guidance. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that every community faces a moment when its "ashqā" (most wretched one) emerges to embody its collective deviation. In the context of Thamud’s rejection of Prophet Salih, this "wretched one" symbolises those who actively resist truth and martyr the sacred symbols of God – here, the she-camel sent as a divine sign.  

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that this verse transcends its historical context, warning every generation: "The most wretched in any era is he who kills the heir of the Prophet’s wisdom." This points to the Shia understanding of Imamah – that rejecting the divinely appointed guides after the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) is the epitome of wretchedness. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasised this in her Fadak sermon, declaring: "God made obedience to us [the Ahlul Bayt] the system for the Ummah and our Imamah a protection against disunity."  

Spiritually, the "ashqā" represents the nafs al-ammāra (the soul that commands evil) within us when it dominates. Practical guidance lies in heeding Imam Ali’s counsel: "Purify your hearts through wilayah [allegiance to divine guardians] and distance yourselves from what darkens the soul." To avoid becoming agents of wretchedness, one must anchor themselves in love for the Ahlul Bayt, embody their ethical teachings, and recognise that true prosperity lies in submitting to the Imam of one’s time – the living guide who illuminates the path to God. As the verse concludes with the soul’s accountability (91:9-10), we are reminded that only through aligning with the Ma’sumīn (infallibles) can we attain tazkiyah (self-purification) and escape the fate of the "ashqā.

العزان از تبتابائی نے اس تجزیے کو استعاراتی طور پر وسعت دی ہے ، جس سے کوڈر کے عمل کو * ولیہ * (خدائی سرپرستی) کے اجتماعی رد jection عمل کے خاتمے کے طور پر تیار کیا گیا ہے۔ شیا الہیات میں ، شیا الہیات میں ، متوازی علامتوں کے ذریعہ ثالثی کی گئی ، خدا کے اختیار کی علامت ، وہ-کیمیل کے اعزاز میں تھامود کی ناکامی۔ اس طرح یہ آیت ان برادریوں کے بارے میں ایک احتیاطی کہانی بن جاتی ہے جو الہی نگرانی سے زیادہ دنیاوی طاقت (*ٹیگوت*) کو استحقاق دیتے ہیں۔

12.layer5:
The verse’s reference to “the most wretched” (*ashqā*) emerging among Thamud’s people is universally interpreted across traditions as alluding to the individual who slaughtered Prophet Salih’s she-camel, defying divine law. Both Sunni and Shia exegetes, including Tabari and Tabatabai, contextualize this within Thamud’s narrative (Quran 7:73–79), agreeing that the act precipitated their destruction. Consensus exists on the verse’s moral lesson: rejection of prophetic guidance invites divine retribution, emphasizing human accountability.  

Sunni commentaries, such as Ibn Kathir’s *Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim* and Qurtubi’s *Al-Jami*, focus on the individual’s moral agency, identifying *ashqā* as Qudar ibn Salif—a figure embodying personal depravity. Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* extends this to theological discussions on free will, framing the act as a consequence of conscious rebellion. Shia sources, including Al-Mizan and Majma al-Bayan, while acknowledging the historical agent, often emphasize systemic societal corruption. Tabrisi and Tusi highlight the role of Thamud’s leadership in enabling oppression, reflecting Shia theological concerns about unjust authority opposing divine guidance.  

Divergences emerge in hermeneutical priorities. Sunni interpretations stress individual accountability, aligning with broader themes of personal responsibility in Sunni theology. Shia exegesis, particularly in Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, occasionally incorporates traditions from the Ahl al-Bayt framing *ashqā* as symbolic of entrenched societal injustice, resonating with Shia emphasis on moral leadership and resistance to tyranny. These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni emphasis on textual literalism and individual ethics versus Shia focus on socio-political implications of Quranic narratives.  

Historically, these interpretive trajectories reflect evolving scholarly contexts. Sunni tafsir developed alongside caliphal patronage, prioritizing stability through individual piety, while Shia scholarship, shaped by experiences of marginalization, often linked Quranic lessons to communal resilience and ethical governance. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core warning against transgressing divine limits, demonstrating shared ethical foundations despite methodological diversity.

13.layer1:
In Surah Ash-Shams verse 13, Prophet Salih addresses his people, the Thamud, with a divine warning: "The messenger of Allah said to them, '[Do not harm] the she-camel of Allah or [prevent her from] her drink.'" This verse centers on the miraculous she-camel (*naqat Allah*) sent by Allah as both a test and a mercy. The Thamud, an ancient Arabian tribe, demanded a sign to validate Salih’s prophethood. Allah created the she-camel from a rock, designating her as a shared resource: she would drink from the community’s water source one day, leaving it for the people the next. The phrase *suqyaha* (her drink) underscores her divinely ordained right to access water—a vital resource in the desert—emphasizing fairness and trust in Allah’s provision.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allameh Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights this narrative as a lesson in recognizing divine authority and resisting greed. The Thamud’s eventual hamstringing of the she-camel symbolized their rejection of Salih’s message and Allah’s laws, leading to their destruction. The term *naqat Allah* elevates the camel beyond a mere animal; she represents Allah’s covenant, testing human stewardship and humility. For Shia thought, this aligns with the principle of *wilayah* (divine guardianship), where rejecting rightful guidance—whether from prophets or Imams—invites spiritual and material ruin.

Today, this verse urges Muslims to honor ethical boundaries in resource use, promote communal welfare over individualism, and heed divinely appointed guidance. It critiques modern exploitation of natural resources, greed-driven inequity, and dismissal of moral leadership. Just as the Thamud were tested through the she-camel, believers today are tested through their treatment of Allah’s blessings and their adherence to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings—reminding us that true success lies in submission to divine wisdom, not transient desires.
13.layer2:
In Surah Ash-Shams verse 13, the "she-camel of Allah" (naqat Allah) emerges as a pivotal symbol of divine trial and prophetic authority in classical Shia exegesis. The verse references Prophet Salih’s warning to the Thamud people against harming the sacred she-camel, a miraculous sign (ayah) granted to them by Allah. As articulated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the she-camel’s sanctity derived from its status as a divine test (ibtila’), embodying both Allah’s mercy and a measure of the people’s moral capacity. Tabrisi notes that the phrase "suqyaha" (her drink) underscores the equitable distribution of resources as a divine command, with the she-camel entitled to drink from the water source on alternate days—a stipulation the Thamud violated, reflecting their greed and rejection of social justice.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this theme theologically, framing the she-camel as a manifestation of Allah’s covenant and a litmus test for obedience to prophetic guidance. The Thamud’s subsequent hamstringing of the she-camel symbolizes not merely physical transgression but a metaphysical rebellion against divine authority (wilayah), a concept central to Shia thought. Their act epitomizes the rejection of *tawhid* in practice, despite verbal affirmations, highlighting the inseparability of faith and righteous action. 

Shia commentators universally link this narrative to the principle of adherence to divine representatives (awliya’), with Salih’s role paralleling the Imams’ function as guardians of spiritual and temporal order. The Thamud’s destruction serves as a caution against opposing divinely ordained leadership, a theme recurrent in Shia historiography and jurisprudence. This verse thus reinforces the doctrinal nexus between prophetic missions, communal accountability, and the consequences of disregarding covenantal obligations—a framework that informs Shia understandings of moral responsibility and divine justice.
13.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Ash-Shams 91:13 is often interpreted as a profound ethical mandate rooted in divine stewardship. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes that Prophet Salih’s warning to the Thamud—to respect the she-camel’s right to water—symbolizes a broader Qur’anic principle: the interdiction of monopolizing natural resources. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali expand this to critique exploitative capitalism and environmental degradation, framing the verse as a call for ecological justice. The “she-camel of Allah” becomes a metaphor for Earth’s delicate ecosystems, urging humanity to balance consumption with preservation.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with debates on water scarcity—a crisis affecting 2 billion people today. The she-camel’s “drink” (suqyaha) mirrors contemporary demands for equitable water distribution, a theme amplified by scholars like Dr. Leila Chamankhah, who links Qur’anic ecology to sustainable development goals. Philosophically, the narrative challenges anthropocentrism, aligning with eco-theology movements that position humans as custodians, not conquerors, of nature.  

Socially, the verse critiques greed and inequality, themes echoed in Imam Khamenei’s calls for economic systems prioritizing communal welfare over profit. Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, which similarly ties environmental care to spiritual duty. Multiculturally, the story bridges Islamic ethics with global activism, such as Indigenous water protectors’ efforts, illustrating shared values across traditions.  

Ultimately, this verse transcends its historical context, offering a timeless framework for addressing climate change, resource conflicts, and ethical governance—a divine reminder that harming “Allah’s she-camel” is tantamount to violating the sacred balance of existence.
13.layer4:
The verse concerning Prophet Salih’s warning to his people about safeguarding Allah’s she-camel carries profound spiritual symbolism illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that the “she-camel of Allah” represents divine blessings and sacred trusts entrusted to humanity, while “her drink” signifies the spiritual sustenance flowing from Allah’s mercy. The Thamud’s transgression in harming the she-camel symbolizes the rejection of divine guidance, a theme deeply tied to the concept of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). The Imam explained, “Every nation has its she-camel—its covenant with Allah—and its drink is the light of guidance. Whoever severs the drink has extinguished the light of their soul” (*Tafsir al-Qummi*).  

The Ahlul Bayt emphasize that just as the she-camel was a test for the Thamud, the recognition and protection of divine authority (*Imamah*) is the ultimate trial for humanity. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) stated, “Allah places His signs among His creation to distinguish the truthful from the liar” (*Bihar al-Anwar*). The she-camel’s sanctity mirrors the sanctity of the Imams, who are the “springs of Allah’s wisdom” and the source of life for hearts. To harm their rights or deny their spiritual nourishment is to repeat the Thamud’s fatal error.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to honor and defend the symbols of Allah’s mercy—beginning with unwavering loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, “Guard the covenant of Allah by guarding His representatives on earth” (*Nahj al-Balagha*). Spiritual development lies in quenching one’s soul through the “drink” of the Imams’ teachings: reciting the Qur’an with their interpretation, seeking their intercession, and embodying justice as they did. To neglect this is to let the soul wither, like a camel deprived of water. Let every believer become a guardian of truth, preserving the sacred and resisting oppression, as Salih urged his people.

کلاسیکی شیعہ طافس ، جیسے آلیمہ تبتابائی کے *المزان *، اس داستان کو خدائی اتھارٹی کو تسلیم کرنے اور لالچ کے خلاف مزاحمت کے سبق کے طور پر اجاگر کرتا ہے۔ تھمود کی حتمی طور پر ہیمسٹرنگ نے شی-کیمیل کو ان کے سلیہ کے پیغام اور اللہ کے قوانین کو مسترد کرنے کی علامت کی ، جس کی وجہ سے ان کی تباہی ہوئی۔ اصطلاح * نقاط اللہ * اونٹ کو محض جانور سے آگے بڑھاتا ہے۔ وہ اللہ کے عہد کی نمائندگی کرتی ہے ، جو انسانی ذمہ داری اور عاجزی کی جانچ کرتی ہے۔ شیعہ کے خیال کے ل this ، یہ * ولیہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کے اصول کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جہاں حقدار رہنمائی کو مسترد کرتے ہیں - چاہے انبیاء یا اماموں سے - روحانی اور مادی بربادی کو ختم کردیں۔

آج ، یہ آیت مسلمانوں پر زور دیتی ہے کہ وہ وسائل کے استعمال میں اخلاقی حدود کا احترام کرے ، انفرادیت پر فرقہ وارانہ فلاح و بہبود کو فروغ دے ، اور الہی مقرر کردہ رہنمائی پر عمل کریں۔ یہ قدرتی وسائل کے جدید استحصال ، لالچ سے چلنے والی عدم مساوات ، اور اخلاقی قیادت کو برخاست کرنے پر تنقید کرتا ہے۔ جس طرح تھامود کا ہی وہ کیمیل کے ذریعہ تجربہ کیا گیا تھا ، اسی طرح مومنین کا آج اللہ کی برکتوں کے ساتھ سلوک اور اہل بیت کی تعلیمات پر ان کی پابندی کے ذریعہ تجربہ کیا جاتا ہے۔ یہ ہمیں یہ تسلیم کرتا ہے کہ حقیقی کامیابی الہی حکمت کے سلسلے میں ہے ، عارضی خواہشات نہیں۔
13.layer2_urdu:
سورہ ایش شیمس آیت 13 میں ، "وہ اللہ کا ہی-اللہ" (نقاط اللہ) کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ میں خدائی آزمائش اور پیشن گوئی کے اختیار کی ایک اہم علامت کے طور پر ابھرا ہے۔ اس آیت کا حوالہ صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم نے تیمود کے لوگوں کو مقدس شی-کیمیل کو نقصان پہنچانے کے خلاف انتباہ کا حوالہ دیا ہے ، یہ ایک معجزاتی علامت (آیہ) اللہ نے دیا تھا۔ جیسا کہ تبریسی کے *ماجما البیان *میں بیان کیا گیا ہے ، وہ اللہ کی رحمت اور لوگوں کی اخلاقی صلاحیت کی ایک پیمائش دونوں کو مجسم بناتے ہوئے ، الہی امتحان (Ibtila ’) کی حیثیت سے اس کی حیثیت سے اخذ کردہ شی-کیمیل کا تقدس ہے۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ "سوکیہہ" (اس کے مشروبات) کے فقرے کو ایک الہی کمانڈ کے طور پر وسائل کی مساوی تقسیم کی نشاندہی کی گئی ہے ، جس میں وہ کیمیل متبادل دنوں میں پانی کے منبع سے پینے کا حقدار ہے۔ تھمود نے ان کے لالچ اور معاشرتی انصاف کو مسترد کرنے کی عکاسی کی ہے۔

تبتابائی کا * المزان * اس موضوع کو مذہبی طور پر وسعت دیتا ہے ، جس سے وہ اللہ کے عہد کا مظہر اور پیشن گوئی کی رہنمائی کی اطاعت کے ل lit ایک لیٹمس ٹیسٹ کے طور پر شیطان کی تشکیل کرتا ہے۔ تھمود کی اس کے بعد ہیمسٹرنگ ہی-کیمیل محض جسمانی حد سے تجاوز نہیں بلکہ الہی اتھارٹی (ولیہ) کے خلاف ایک استعاریاتی بغاوت کی علامت ہے ، جو شیعہ کے خیال کا مرکزی خیال ہے۔ زبانی اثبات کے باوجود ، ان کا ایکٹ عملی طور پر * توہد * کے مسترد ہونے کی علامت ہے ، جس میں ایمان اور نیک عمل کی لازم و ملزومیت کو اجاگر کیا گیا ہے۔ 

شیعہ مبصرین عالمی طور پر اس داستان کو الہی نمائندوں (اولیہ ’) پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے اصول سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، جس میں روحانی اور دنیاوی نظم و ضبط کے سرپرست کی حیثیت سے اماموں کے کام کے متوازی سالہ کا کردار ہے۔ تھامود کی تباہی مخالف الہی مقررہ قیادت کے خلاف احتیاط کا باعث ہے ، جو شیعہ تاریخ نگاری اور فقہ میں ایک موضوع بار بار ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت پیشن گوئی کے مشنوں ، فرقہ وارانہ احتساب ، اور عہد نامے کی ذمہ داریوں کو نظرانداز کرنے کے نتائج کے مابین نظریاتی گٹھ جوڑ کو تقویت دیتی ہے۔ یہ ایک ایسا فریم ورک ہے جو شیعہ کو اخلاقی ذمہ داری اور خدائی انصاف کی تفہیم سے آگاہ کرتا ہے۔
13.layer3_urdu:
عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ ایش شیمس 91:13 کو اکثر الہی ذمہ داری میں جڑے ہوئے ایک گہرے اخلاقی مینڈیٹ کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے استقامت میں اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کے تیمود کو انتباہ کریں-وہ اس کیمیل کے پانی کے حق کا احترام کریں-ایک وسیع تر قرآنی اصول کو ہم آہنگ کرتا ہے: قدرتی وسائل کو اجارہ دار بنانے کا مداخلت۔ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے جدید اسکالرز اس کو تنقید کرنے والے استحصالی سرمایہ داری اور ماحولیاتی انحطاط تک بڑھاتے ہیں ، اور اس آیت کو ماحولیاتی انصاف کی کال کے طور پر تیار کرتے ہیں۔ "وہ-اللہ کا-کیمیل" زمین کے نازک ماحولیاتی نظام کا استعارہ بن جاتا ہے ، جس سے انسانیت پر زور دیا جاتا ہے کہ وہ کھپت کو تحفظ کے ساتھ متوازن کرے۔  

سائنسی لحاظ سے ، آیت پانی کی کمی سے متعلق بحثوں کے ساتھ گونجتی ہے۔ یہ بحران آج 2 ارب افراد کو متاثر کرتا ہے۔ وہ-کیمیل کا "مشروب" (سوکیہہ) مساوی پانی کی تقسیم کے عصری مطالبات کا آئینہ دار ہے ، جس کا ایک موضوع ڈاکٹر لیلی چامانکھاہ جیسے اسکالرز نے بڑھایا ہے ، جو قرآنی ماحولیات کو پائیدار ترقیاتی اہداف سے جوڑتا ہے۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، داستان بشریات کو چیلنج کرتا ہے ، جو ماحولیات کی تحریکوں کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے جو انسانوں کو نگران ، فاتح نہیں ، فطرت کے متنازعہ قرار دیتے ہیں۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت میں لالچ اور عدم مساوات پر تنقید کی گئی ہے ، امام خامینی کی معاشی نظام کی کالوں میں موضوعات گونجتے ہیں جو منافع سے زیادہ فرقہ وارانہ فلاح و بہبود کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں۔ پوپ فرانسس ’ *لاؤڈاٹو سی’ *میں انٹرفیتھ کے متوازی سامنے آتے ہیں ، جو اسی طرح ماحولیاتی نگہداشت کو روحانی فرائض سے جوڑتا ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی طور پر ، کہانی عالمی سرگرمی کے ساتھ اسلامی اخلاقیات کو پوش کرتی ہے ، جیسے دیسی واٹر پروٹیکٹرز کی کوششوں ، جو روایات میں مشترکہ اقدار کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔  

آخر کار ، یہ آیت اپنے تاریخی سیاق و سباق سے بالاتر ہے ، جو آب و ہوا کی تبدیلی ، وسائل کے تنازعات ، اور اخلاقی حکمرانی سے نمٹنے کے لئے ایک لازوال فریم ورک کی پیش کش کرتی ہے۔ یہ ایک الہی یاد دہانی ہے کہ "اللہ کی وہ کیمیل" کو نقصان پہنچانا وجود کے مقدس توازن کی خلاف ورزی کرنے کے مترادف ہے۔

اہل بیت اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ جس طرح وہ کیمیل تھامود کے لئے ایک امتحان تھا ، اسی طرح الہی اتھارٹی (*امامہ*) کی پہچان اور تحفظ انسانیت کے لئے حتمی آزمائش ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن ہے) نے کہا ، "اللہ صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم کو جھوٹے سے سچائی کو ممتاز کرنے کے لئے اپنی علامتوں کو اپنی تخلیق میں رکھتا ہے" (*بہار الانور*)۔ وہ کیمیل کا تقدس اماموں کے تقدس کو آئینہ دار کرتا ہے ، جو "اللہ کی حکمت کے چشمے" اور دلوں کے لئے زندگی کا ذریعہ ہیں۔ ان کے حقوق کو نقصان پہنچانے یا ان کی روحانی پرورش سے انکار کرنا تھامود کی مہلک غلطی کو دہرانا ہے۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو اللہ کی رحمت کی علامتوں کا احترام اور ان کا دفاع کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر سلامتی) نے سکھایا ، "زمین پر اپنے نمائندوں کی حفاظت کرکے اللہ کے عہد کی حفاظت کرو" (*ناہج البالاگھا*)۔ روحانی نشوونما اماموں کی تعلیمات کے "مشروب" کے ذریعہ کسی کی روح کو بجھانے میں مضمر ہے: قرآن کو ان کی تشریح کے ساتھ تلاوت کرنا ، ان کی شفاعت کی تلاش ، اور انصاف کو مجسم بنانا جیسے انہوں نے کیا۔ اس کو نظرانداز کرنا یہ ہے کہ روح کو پانی سے محروم رکھنے کی طرح روح کو مرجھانا ہے۔ ہر مومن کو سچائی کا سرپرست بننے ، مقدس کو محفوظ رکھنے اور ظلم و ستم کا مقابلہ کرنے دیں ، جیسا کہ صالح نے اپنے لوگوں پر زور دیا ہے۔
13.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Ash-Shams 91:13, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions converge on core narrative elements while diverging in theological emphasis. The verse recounts Prophet Salih’s warning to Thamud against harming Allah’s she-camel, a miraculous sign. Classical exegetes across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia), agree on the historical context: the she-camel symbolized divine providence and a test of obedience, with its slaughter precipitating Thamud’s destruction. Ibn Kathir and Al-Mizan’s Tabatabai both stress the moral imperative to respect sacred symbols and heed prophetic warnings, framing the narrative as a universal lesson on divine justice.

Key differences emerge in theological underpinnings. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi emphasize the camel as a *muʿjiza* (prophetic miracle) validating Salih’s mission, focusing on the consequences of rejecting clear signs. Shia sources, particularly Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s tafsir, often contextualize the narrative within the broader paradigm of divine guidance (*hidaya*), drawing implicit parallels between Salih’s role and the Imams’ authority as inheritors of prophetic wisdom. Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* extends this to a metaphysical reading, interpreting the she-camel’s protection as symbolic of safeguarding divine truths entrusted to rightful guides.

These interpretive divergences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritizes prophetic historicity and communal accountability, while Shia readings often integrate Imamology into Quranic hermeneutics. Practically, this influences how each tradition applies the verse’s lessons—Sunni discourses may emphasize individual adherence to prophetic teachings, whereas Shia interpretations might reinforce allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt as custodians of divine guidance. Such differences stem from historical developments in theological priorities post-Prophetic era, with Shia scholarship systematically linking Quranic narratives to the Imamate doctrine. Both traditions, however, maintain shared ethical imperatives against transgression and the necessity of heeding divine warnings.

14.layer1:
In Surah Ash-Shams, verse 14 recounts the story of the people of Thamud and their rejection of Prophet Salih (AS). The verse states: *"But they denied him and hamstrung her. So their Lord brought down upon them destruction for their sin and made it equal [upon all of them]."* This refers to the Thamud’s defiance of Allah’s command through Salih (AS), who presented them with a miraculous she-camel (*naqat Allah*) as a divine test. The Arabic term *fa'aqaruha* (they hamstrung her) signifies their violent rejection of this sign—a deliberate act of severing the camel’s tendons, symbolizing their rebellion against both the prophet and Allah’s mercy.  

Historically, Thamud’s elites, led by a man named Qudar ibn Salif, conspired to kill the sacred camel after dismissing Salih’s warnings. Their arrogance (*istikbar*) and greed for resources led them to violate the covenant that the camel would share their water supply. The phrase *damdam alayhim* (brought down destruction) describes Allah’s overwhelming punishment—a catastrophic earthquake or blast—that annihilated them equally, illustrating divine justice’s inevitability.  

Key lessons for contemporary Muslims include heeding prophetic guidance and respecting Allah’s boundaries (*hudud*). The verse warns against prioritizing material gain over ethical principles, as Thamud did by harming the camel to monopolise water. Today, this applies to exploiting resources unjustly, ignoring environmental stewardship, or silencing truth-tellers. The equal destruction (*sawwaha*) emphasises collective responsibility: societies that normalise oppression face shared consequences.  

As Shia teachings stress, upholding justice requires active resistance to tyranny, as Imam Ali (AS) exemplified. This verse reminds believers to value divine signs—whether in scripture, nature, or moral conscience—and to align actions with Allah’s will, fostering communities rooted in taqwa and equity.
14.layer2:
In Surah al-Shams verse 14, classical Shia exegetes emphasize the interplay between human moral agency and divine justice, contextualizing the destruction of Thamud as a consequence of their rejection of Prophet Salih’s covenant. The verse recounts their denial (*takdhib*) and the hamstringing of the sacred she-camel (*‘aqr*), a miraculous sign (āya) granted to them as both a test and a mercy. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* underscores that the she-camel symbolized divine providence; its slaughter represented not merely a physical crime but a metaphysical rebellion against Salih’s authority (nubuwwa) and God’s sovereignty. The term *damdama* (to obliterate) denotes comprehensive annihilation, reflecting the proportionality of divine punishment—a recurring theme in Qur’anic narratives where communities face consequences commensurate with their transgression (miḥqān al-aʿmāl).

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this theological framework, noting that Thamud’s destruction (*fasawwaha*) was not arbitrary but rooted in their persistent moral corruption (fasad), which nullified their capacity for repentance. The “equalizing” (taswiya) of their punishment signifies divine equity—a core Shia theological principle affirming that God’s justice (*‘adl*) operates without oppression (zulm), as He “does not wrong [anyone] even by the weight of an atom” (Qur’an 4:40). This episode also illustrates the Shia doctrine of amr bayna al-amrayn (position between two positions), wherein human free will coexists with divine decree; Thamud’s choice to reject Salih activated preordained consequences embedded in cosmic law (sunan al-kawn). 

Jurisprudentially, classical scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi link this narrative to the inviolability of covenants (ʿahd) in Islamic law, as Thamud violated their pact with Salih. The verse thus serves as an enduring admonition about the societal consequences of rejecting divine guidance (ḥujja) and the ethical imperative to uphold sacred trusts. Through these lenses, Shia tafsir harmonizes historical narrative with transcendent principles of justice, human accountability, and the ontological relationship between divine will and human action.
14.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Ash-Shams verse 14 is often framed as a timeless warning against systemic injustice and ecological disregard. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes that the Thamud’s destruction stemmed not merely from rejecting Prophet Salih (AS) but from violating the sacred balance (mīzān) between humanity, nature, and divine ethics. The she-camel, a miraculous sign, symbolized both economic equity—its milk sustained the community—and the sanctity of life. By “hamstringing” it, the Thamud epitomized greed and violence against creation, triggering their collapse.  

Modern scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim draw parallels to today’s climate crisis, where exploitative practices—deforestation, fossil fuel dependency—mirror the Thamud’s “ecological sin.” The verse’s phrase “made it equal [upon all of them]” underscores collective responsibility: environmental degradation, like divine punishment, spares no social stratum. Philosophically, this aligns with the Shia concept of ‘adl (divine justice), where natural laws and moral accountability intertwine.  

Socially, the verse critiques extractive capitalism and authoritarianism. The Thamud’s elites, as noted by scholar Muhammad Ali Shomali, weaponized power to suppress dissent, much like modern regimes silencing climate activists. Interfaith dialogues highlight resonances with Indigenous stewardship ethics and Christian “creation care,” fostering solidarity in addressing global warming.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges humanity to heed “prophetic warnings”—today voiced by scientists and ethicists—or face self-inflicted ruin. It bridges ancient wisdom and modern urgency, framing sustainability as a sacred duty and collective redemption.
14.layer4:
The verse from Surah Ash-Shams recounts the destruction of Thamud for rejecting Prophet Salih (عليه السلام) and slaughtering the sacred she-camel—a divine test of their submission. The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) unveil profound spiritual dimensions here. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) states, *"The she-camel was a sign (ayah) of Allah’s mercy; to kill her was to kill the spirit of wilayah (divine guardianship) in their souls."* This connects the physical act to the spiritual crime of rejecting divine guidance embodied in the Imamah. The she-camel symbolised the Imam’s role: a living miracle demanding recognition and reverence.  

Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) taught that *"sins against the covenant of Allah darken the heart until it becomes a ruin, like the ruins of Thamud."* The verse’s phrase "fa-sawwaha" (He made it equal) is interpreted as Allah rendering their hearts and deeds uniformly barren—a consequence of persistently opposing truth. Imam Ali (عليه السلام) warns in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Whoever equates the command of Allah with their desires is destroyed, as Thamud were destroyed."*  

Spiritually, this verse cautions against the "hamstringing" of divine truths through arrogance or worldly attachment. The Thamud’s fate mirrors the inner collapse awaiting those who sever their connection to the Imam’s guidance. Practical wisdom lies in daily self-accountability: Do we "slaughter" the sacred by prioritizing ego over the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings? The path of wilayah demands nurturing gratitude for divine signs, upholding justice (as the she-camel represented equitable resource-sharing), and embracing the Imamah as the lifeline to Allah’s mercy. As Imam al-Baqir (عليه السلام) said, *"The she-camel’s water was life for Thamud; the Imam’s knowledge is life for your souls."* Let us drink deeply.

سورہ ایش شیمس میں ، آیت 14 نے تھامود کے لوگوں کی کہانی اور ان کے نبی صلی الیہ (ع) کو مسترد کرنے کی کہانی سنائی ہے۔ آیت میں کہا گیا ہے:*"لیکن انہوں نے اس سے انکار کیا اور اسے ہیمسٹرنگ کیا۔ لہذا ان کے رب نے ان کے گناہ کی وجہ سے تباہی لائی اور [ان سب پر] اس کو برابر کردیا۔ عربی اصطلاح * فاکاروہا * (وہ اس کو متاثر کرتے ہیں) اس علامت کو ان کے پرتشدد مسترد کرنے کی نشاندہی کرتے ہیں۔ اونٹ کے کنڈرا کو الگ کرنے کا ایک دانستہ عمل ، نبی اور اللہ کی رحمت دونوں کے خلاف ان کی بغاوت کی علامت ہے۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، تھامود کے اشرافیہ ، جس کی سربراہی کوڈر ابن سیلیف نامی شخص نے کی تھی ، نے صالح کی انتباہات کو مسترد کرنے کے بعد مقدس اونٹ کو مارنے کی سازش کی۔ ان کے تکبر (*استک بار*) اور وسائل کے لالچ کی وجہ سے وہ اس عہد کی خلاف ورزی کرتے ہیں کہ اونٹ اپنی پانی کی فراہمی میں شریک ہوگا۔ جملے * ددم الہیم * (تباہی کو ختم کرنے کے لئے) اللہ کی زبردست سزا کو بیان کرتا ہے۔  

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے کلیدی اسباق میں پیشن گوئی کی رہنمائی پر عمل کرنا اور اللہ کی حدود کا احترام کرنا شامل ہے (*hudud*)۔ آیت اخلاقی اصولوں پر مادی فائدہ کو ترجیح دینے کے خلاف متنبہ کرتی ہے ، جیسا کہ تھامود نے اونٹ کو پانی کو اجارہ دار بنانے کے لئے نقصان پہنچاتے ہوئے کیا تھا۔ آج ، اس کا اطلاق غیر منصفانہ وسائل کے استحصال ، ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری کو نظرانداز کرنے ، یا سچ بولنے والوں کو خاموش کرنے پر ہوتا ہے۔ مساوی تباہی (*سوواہا*) اجتماعی ذمہ داری پر زور دیتی ہے: معاشرے جو ظلم کو معمول پر لاتے ہیں انہیں مشترکہ نتائج کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے۔  

جیسا کہ شیعہ تعلیمات پر زور دیا جاتا ہے ، انصاف کو برقرار رکھنے کے لئے ظلم کے خلاف فعال مزاحمت کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے ، جیسا کہ امام علی (ع) کی مثال ہے۔ یہ آیت مومنوں کو الہی علامتوں کی قدر کرنے کی یاد دلاتی ہے - چاہے وہ صحیفہ ، فطرت ، یا اخلاقی ضمیر میں ہو - اور اللہ کی مرضی کے ساتھ کام کرنے کے لئے ، تقوا اور ایکویٹی میں جڑی ہوئی جماعتوں کو فروغ دینا۔

14.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Ash-Shams 14, which recounts the destruction of Thamud for rejecting Prophet Salih and killing the sacred she-camel, Shia and Sunni exegetes share core narrative and theological foundations. Both traditions, as seen in Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, affirm the historical reality of the event, emphasizing divine justice in punishing collective transgression. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* concur that the verse underscores the consequences of defying prophetic guidance, with the phrase “made it equal” interpreted universally as equitable punishment for shared complicity in sin. Qurtubi and Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* both highlight the she-camel’s symbolic role as a divine miracle testing Thamud’s obedience.

Key divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Shia commentaries, particularly Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, often frame the narrative as a paradigm for rejecting divinely appointed leadership (wilayah), drawing implicit parallels to the persecution of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tabatabai expands this to discuss moral corruption as a societal collapse when truth is abandoned. Sunni scholars like Razi in *Mafatih al-Ghayb* focus more on theodicy, analyzing divine attributes in punishment, while Ibn Kathir stresses literal-historical details to reinforce prophetic authority. These differences reflect distinct hermeneutical priorities: Shia tafsir frequently integrates Imamite hadith to derive ethical and doctrinal lessons, whereas classical Sunni exegesis prioritizes philological analysis and transmission chains (isnad) from companions.

Both traditions agree the verse warns against communal sin, but their applications differ subtly. Shia discourse may emphasize loyalty to spiritual guides as a protective principle, while Sunni interpretations often highlight individual accountability alongside communal responsibility. Historically, these approaches stem from differing epistemological frameworks, with Shia scholarship privileging the Imams’ hermeneutical authority and Sunni exegesis rooted in companion-based transmission. Such variations enrich Islamic intellectual heritage without negating shared ethical and theological foundations.

In Surah Ash-Shams, verse 15, Allah declares, *"Wa la yakhafu uqbaha"* ("And He does not fear the consequence thereof"), concluding a passage that contrasts divine justice with human accountability. This verse follows Allah’s oath by His magnificent creations—the sun, moon, day, night, and the human soul—emphasizing that He alone holds the power to purify or corrupt souls. Historically, this surah is linked to the story of the Thamud people, who rejected Prophet Salih and were destroyed for their arrogance and oppression. The verse underscores Allah’s absolute authority: His judgment is inevitable, and He faces no "uqbaha" (consequence or repercussion) for enacting justice, as His actions are inherently perfect and beyond reproach.

The term *"uqbaha"* (consequence) here refers to outcomes or backlash, highlighting a key theological principle in Shia thought: Allah’s justice (*‘adl*) is inseparable from His wisdom (*hikma*). Unlike humans, who might hesitate due to fear of unintended results, Allah’s decisions are flawlessly aligned with truth. Classical Shia commentators like Allama Tabatabai explain that this verse reassures believers that divine punishment is never arbitrary; it is a direct response to human choices, as seen in the fate of Thamud. The verse also affirms Allah’s transcendence—He is not bound by the limitations or vulnerabilities that shape human actions.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on trust in divine justice. In a world where oppression often seems unchecked, it reminds us that ultimate accountability lies with Allah, whose judgment is fearless and final. Practically, this fosters patience during hardship and encourages ethical courage: just as Allah acts without fear of consequence in upholding justice, Muslims are called to stand for truth, even when it risks personal loss. It also cautions against arrogance, as no power can evade the Creator’s reckoning. By internalizing this truth, believers can navigate modern challenges with both humility and resolve, anchored in the certainty of divine justice.

In Surah Ash-Shams (91:15), the phrase "And He does not fear the consequence thereof" has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as an affirmation of divine justice (*‘adl*) and the absolute sovereignty of Allah. The verse concludes the narrative of the destruction of Thamud, who rejected the she-camel sent as a divine sign. As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, the pronoun "He" refers to Allah, whose actions—including the annihilation of transgressors—are inherently just and beyond reproach. Since divine punishment is never arbitrary but a direct consequence of human moral failure, Allah "does not fear" any imbalance or injustice arising from His decree. This reflects the Shia theological principle that Allah’s acts are inseparable from His wisdom (*ḥikmah*), rendering any "consequence" of His judgment inherently aligned with cosmic truth.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this concept by situating the verse within the surah’s broader framework: the oath sworn by natural phenomena (sun, moon, day, night) and the human soul underscores the inescapability of divine accountability. The "consequence" Allah does not fear is not a literal outcome but a rhetorical negation of any deficiency in His judgment. Shia scholars emphasize that while humans must fear the repercussions of their choices, Allah transcends such concerns, as His justice is absolute. This aligns with the doctrine of *lutf* (divine grace), wherein Allah’s actions optimally guide creation without compulsion.

The verse also resonates with Shia eschatology, linking divine judgment to the *wilayah* (guardianship) of the Ahl al-Bayt. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq noted, rejection of divine guidance—symbolized by Thamud’s defiance—invites ruin, while adherence to the Imams ensures alignment with Allah’s unerring justice. Thus, the verse reinforces the necessity of moral and spiritual vigilance, integral to Shia jurisprudence’s focus on intention (*niyyah*) and ethical responsibility.

Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames this verse as a reminder that Allah’s actions—unlike human decisions—are rooted in absolute wisdom and justice, transcending worldly calculations of “consequence.” Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to humanity’s ethical responsibility: just as Allah’s justice is unclouded by fear, humans must act courageously against oppression, environmental harm, or social inequity, trusting in divine wisdom over short-term fears.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with ecological principles: Earth’s systems operate under laws of balance (e.g., climate feedback loops), yet human disruption—driven by greed or apathy—defies this natural harmony. Philosopher Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi links the verse to the “cosmic trust” (amana) in Quranic thought, urging societies to align with sustainable, ethical systems rather than exploitative models that fear no accountability.  

In today’s context, this verse critiques systems prioritizing profit over planetary health or political power over human dignity. It challenges interfaith communities to collaborate on climate justice and poverty alleviation, recognizing shared values of stewardship. Multicultural dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Mahdi Institute, highlight how divine fearlessness in justice inspires interreligious solidarity against authoritarianism or xenophobia.

15.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Ash-Shams (91:15), Allah declares His absolute sovereignty with the words "And He does not fear the consequence thereof," revealing a profound truth about divine action. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that this verse unveils the perfection of Allah’s justice and the unshakable harmony of His cosmic order. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Allah’s command descends with justice as its reins and mercy as its companion."* Here, "not fearing consequence" signifies that divine actions arise from absolute wisdom, needing no justification before creation, for His justice is inseparable from His essence.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that this verse also reflects the station of the divinely appointed Imams, whose actions align perfectly with Allah’s will. He said: *"The Imam acts by the light of Allah, neither fearing criticism nor seeking praise."* Just as Allah’s decree transcends reproach, the Imam’s wilayah (divine guardianship) operates beyond worldly calculations, guiding souls toward eternal truth. This principle manifests in the lives of the Infallibles, such as Imam Hussain’s stand at Karbala—a seemingly catastrophic event in earthly terms, yet a cosmic triumph in divine wisdom.

For spiritual growth, this verse invites believers to trust Allah’s plan unconditionally, even when trials seem incomprehensible. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) exemplified this when she said: *"Allah makes His pleasure your pleasure, so be content as He is content."* By aligning one’s will with the Imam’s teachings—surrendering personal fears and doubts—the believer transcends limited perception, embracing the certainty that divine justice prevails. Let every hardship be met with the remembrance that Allah’s plan, like the sun’s radiant course in this very Surah, follows a flawless path whose end is only light.

15.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Ash-Shams 15 (“And He does not fear the consequence thereof”), Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur that the verse emphasizes Allah’s absolute sovereignty and transcendence beyond human notions of accountability. Both traditions, as noted in Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, contextualize the verse within the preceding narrative of Thamud’s destruction, affirming that divine punishment arises from perfect justice, requiring no justification or apprehension of repercussions. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi similarly stress Allah’s omnipotence, with Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) underscoring that divine actions transcend cause-effect relationships governing creation.

A key divergence emerges in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) and Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) focus on Allah’s self-sufficiency (غنى ذاتي), interpreting the verse as reinforcing tawhid through divine independence from creation’s constraints. Shia sources, particularly Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, extend this principle to theodicy, framing the verse as a rejection of anthropocentric critiques of divine decree. Al-Qummi links the “consequence” to the spiritual ramifications of rejecting divinely appointed guides (Ahl al-Bayt), reflecting the Shia emphasis on Imamah as integral to cosmic balance.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes Allah’s transcendence in isolation, while Shia tafsir frequently integrates Imamah into cosmological principles. Practically, this shapes divergent emphases in moral reasoning—Sunni interpretations may stress individual accountability before an omnipotent God, whereas Shia readings connect divine justice to adherence to prophetic legacy embodied in the Imams. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a profound affirmation of divine majesty beyond human comprehension, demonstrating how shared textual foundations yield complementary spiritual insights across Islamic thought.

سورہ ایش شیمس کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے 15 ("اور اسے اس کے نتیجے میں خوف نہیں آتا ہے") ، شیعہ اور سنی نے بڑے پیمانے پر اس بات پر اتفاق کیا کہ آیت میں اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری اور احتساب کے انسانی تصورات سے بالاتر ہونے پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔ دونوں روایات ، جیسا کہ تباری کے *جامی البیان *اور تبتابائی کے *المزان *میں نوٹ کیا گیا ہے ، تھامود کی تباہی کی سابقہ ​​داستان کے اندر آیت کو سیاق و سباق میں بنائیں ، اس بات کی تصدیق کرتے ہوئے کہ الہی سزا کامل انصاف سے پیدا ہوتی ہے ، جس میں کوئی جواز یا ذخیرے کی ضرورت نہیں ہوتی ہے۔ ابن کتھیر اور تبریسی بھی اسی طرح اللہ کے قہقہے پر زور دیتے ہیں ، جس میں تبریسی (*مجس البیان*) کے ساتھ اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ الہی عمل تخلیق کے اثر و رسوخ کے تعلقات سے بالاتر ہیں۔

مذہبی مضمرات میں ایک اہم موڑ ابھرتا ہے۔ سنی کے مبصرین جیسے قربانی (*الجامی لی -حکام*) اور ریزی (*مافاتیہ الغیب*) اللہ کی خود کفالت (اِنى اوتھی) پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، اور تخلیق کی رکاوٹوں سے الہی آزادی کے ذریعے تاؤھیڈ کو تقویت دینے کے طور پر آیت کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ کے ذرائع ، خاص طور پر توسی کے *ایٹ تبیان *اور قمی کے *طافسیر القمی *، اس اصول کو تھیوڈیسی تک بڑھا دیتے ہیں ، اور اس آیت کو الہی فرمان کے انسانیت کی تنقیدوں کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ القمی نے خدائی طور پر مقرر کردہ ہدایت نامہ (اے ایچ ایل البائٹ) کو مسترد کرنے کے روحانی اثر و رسوخ سے "نتیجہ" کو جوڑ دیا ہے ، جو امامہ پر شیعہ کے زور کو کائناتی توازن کے لازمی قرار دیتے ہیں۔

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: سنی کی اصلاح اکثر اللہ کی تنہائی میں عبور کو ترجیح دیتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ طافسر اکثر امامہ کو کائناتی اصولوں میں ضم کرتا ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ اخلاقی استدلال میں مختلف زور دیتا ہے۔ سنی تشریحات ایک متنازعہ خدا کے سامنے انفرادی احتساب پر زور دے سکتی ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ ریڈنگ الہی انصاف کو اماموں میں شامل پیشن گوئی وراثت کی پیروی سے مربوط کرتی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کو انسانی فہم سے بالاتر الہی عظمت کی گہری تصدیق کے طور پر دیکھنے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں ، جس سے یہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے کہ مشترکہ متنی بنیادوں کو اسلامی فکر میں کس طرح تکمیلی روحانی بصیرت ملتی ہے۔
